Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling is preparing for a stressful final exam and is feeling anxious about the outcome.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I stared at my phone, the clock ticking down the last hour of my shift. My sales numbers glared at me from the screen—still three short of the weekly target. If I didn’t make it, my manager would definitely have a word with me, maybe even cut my hours. I took a deep breath, ready to dial the next number, when my stepbrother’s name flashed on my phone. He never called during the day unless it was important. I remembered this morning, how pale he looked, hunched over his textbooks, muttering about failing his final exam. I knew he needed me, probably just to talk, to hear that he’d be okay. But every minute I spent on the phone with him was a minute I wasn’t making calls, wasn’t closing sales. My job demanded focus, numbers, results. My family—my brother—needed comfort, reassurance, someone to listen. My thumb hovered over the answer button, my heart pounding, torn between the voice of my manager in my head and the shaky voice I imagined on the other end of the line.
